turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about JNR dismissal lawsuit.
turn.2: JNR dismissal lawsuit The JNR dismissal lawsuit is a lawsuit that resulted from the privatization of Japanese National Railways (JNR) in 1987, and its breakup into the seven Japan Railways Group companies.
turn.3: Why did they settle the lawsuit?
turn.4: In March 1990, 1,047 mostly union workers were laid off, 966 of whom were from the National Railway Workers' Union (Kokuro), and two decades of lawsuits followed.
turn.5: What was the final amount of the lawsuit?
turn.6: The dispute was eventually settled in June 2010 for 20 billion yen, or about 22 million yen per worker for 904 plaintiffs.
turn.7: Was there any other interesting information?
turn.8: JNR, organized as a public corporation in 1949, had become unprofitable over subsequent decades.
turn.10: In the 1980s the Liberal Democratic Party government of prime minister Yasuhiro Nakasone decided to privatize the organization.
turn.11: Why were they able to profit after the privatization?
turn.12: Around this time other government bodies were also either wholly or partially privatized, such as Japan Tobacco and NTT in 1985.
